html.title: HTML Basics
html.content:
##Welcome to the HTML Basics lesson! In this lesson, we'll cover the essential elements of HTML to get you started on your web development journey.

HTML, which stands for HyperText Markup Language, is the standard language used to create and design web pages.
In this lesson, you'll discover:

1. The purpose and usage of the DOCTYPE declaration.
2. Basic HTML structure and elements.
3. How to view the HTML source code of a web page.
html.lesson:
##Understanding the DOCTYPE Declaration

The DOCTYPE declaration is an essential part of an HTML document. It specifies the version of HTML being used and helps web browsers render the page correctly. Here's an example of the DOCTYPE declaration for HTML5:

`<!DOCTYPE html>`

This declaration should be placed at the beginning of every HTML document to ensure compatibility and proper rendering.

##Basic HTML Structure

An HTML document consists of several basic elements, including:

1. <html>: This tag marks the beginning and end of your webpage. All other elements are placed inside it. It should always be closed at the end of the document, like this <\html>.

2. <head>: Within this tag, you include important information about your webpage, like its title, keywords, and references to other files.  It should be closed -<\head>- before the <body> tag starts.

3. <body>: Inside this tag, you put all the content that users see when they visit your webpage, like text, images, and links. It should be closed at the end of the document - <\body>.

4. <title>: This tag sets the title of your webpage, which appears at the top of the browser window or tab. It's self-contained within the <head> section.

5. <meta>: These tags provide additional information about your webpage, such as its character encoding and viewport settings. They are self-closing tags and do not require a separate closing tag.

##Viewing HTML Source Code

Ever stumbled upon a webpage that made you go, "Wow, how did they do that?" Let's unlock the mystery!
View HTML Source Code:
Click CTRL + U in an HTML page, or right-click on the page and select "View Page Source". This will open a new tab containing the HTML source code of the page.

quiz.question: What is the purpose of the DOCTYPE declaration in an HTML document?
options: A) It specifies the version of JavaScript used.
B) It helps web browsers render the page correctly.
C) It defines the layout and design of the webpage.
D) It determines the character encoding of the webpage.

quiz.question: Which tag marks the beginning and end of an HTML webpage and should always be closed at the end of the document?
How can you view the HTML source code of a webpage?
options: B) Right-click and select "View Page Source"

html.title: HTML Elements and Attributes
html.content:
##1. The essence of HTML elements and their significance in web design.
##2. Understanding the syntax of HTML elements and the role of attributes in providing additional information about elements.
##3. Exploring various attributes and HTML elements in action.
html.lesson:
##Elements syntax unveiled: HTML utilizes elements as its core components. An HTML element is comprised of three main parts: 1. Start tag: It marks the beginning of an element and is enclosed within angle brackets (< and >). For instance, . 2. Element content: This is the actual content encapsulated by the element. It could be text, images, or other elements. 3. End tag: It denotes the conclusion of an element and is similar to the start tag, except it includes a forward slash before the tag name. For example, . Additionally, some elements may be empty, meaning they don't contain any content and thus don't require an end tag. These are known as empty elements. ##Elements in Action: Let's explore some examples to better grasp how HTML elements function: `

My First Heading

This is a
paragraph with a line break.

` In this example, you can see already familiar elements such as , , and . You'll also encounter an empty element,
, which represents a line break and is an empty element. Empty elements like
don't have a closing tag because they don't contain any content. ##Attributes HTML attributes provide additional information about elements and are always specified within the start tag of an element. 1. The href attribute is commonly used with the tag to define hyperlinks. It specifies the URL of the page the link goes to. For example: `Visit Example` 2. The src attribute is utilized with the tag to embed images in HTML pages. It specifies the path to the image to be displayed. ` ` 3. The width and height attributes define the width and height of an image in pixels, ensuring proper display. `` 4. The alt attribute provides alternate text for images, which is displayed if the image cannot be loaded. `` 5. The style attribute adds inline styles to elements, allowing customization of appearance. `

Styled paragraph

` 6. The lang attribute specifies the language of the HTML document, assisting search engines and browsers. `` 7. The title attribute provides additional information about an element, displayed as a tooltip when hovered over. `

Hello

` ##Single or Double Quotes? Double quotes around attribute values are the most common in HTML, but single quotes can also be used. In some situations, when the attribute value itself contains double quotes, it is necessary to use single quotes: `

Hello

`

html.title: Your First HTML Paragraph
html.content:
##By now, you've gained a solid understanding of HTML basics and elements, including attributes. In this lesson, we'll put that knowledge into practice by creating your first paragraph in HTML.
##Recap of What You've Learned:

1. You've learned about the essential elements of HTML, such as <html>, <head>, <body>, <title>, and <meta>.
2. You've discovered the significance of the DOCTYPE declaration in specifying the HTML version and ensuring proper rendering.
3. You've explored HTML elements and their syntax, including start tags, element content, and end tags.
4. You've delved into the role of attributes in providing additional information about elements, and you've seen various attributes commonly used in HTML elements.
##Now, let's apply this knowledge to create your first paragraph in HTML!
html.lesson:
##Creating Your First Paragraph: To create a paragraph in HTML, we use the

element. This element allows us to structure text content into paragraphs on our web page. Here's a simple example of how to create your first paragraph in HTML: ` My First Web Page

Welcome to My Web Page!

This is my first paragraph in HTML. I'm learning how to create web pages, and it's exciting!

` In this example: 1. We've started with the DOCTYPE declaration () to specify the HTML version. 2. Inside the element, we've included the section, where we've set the title of our web page using the element. 3. The <body> element contains the visible content of our web page. We've added an <h1> element for the main heading (don’t panic! you will learn about headings in the subsequent lessons) and a <p> element for our paragraph. Feel free to customize the content of the paragraph to reflect your own thoughts, ideas, or any information you'd like to share on your web page. ##Congratulations! You've successfully created your first paragraph in HTML. Keep practicing and exploring new elements and attributes to enhance your web development skills.

css.title: CSS Margins
css.content: In this lesson, you'll learn how to use CSS margin properties to create space around elements.
css.lesson:
Margins are used to create space around elements, outside of any defined borders.

CSS has properties for specifying the margin for each side of an element:
1. margin-top
2. margin-right
3. margin-bottom
5. margin-left
All the margin properties can have the following values:
1. auto - the browser calculates the margin
2. length - specifies a margin in px, pt, cm, etc.
3. % - specifies a margin in % of the width of the containing element
4. inherit - specifies that the margin should be inherited from the parent element
##Example:
`p {
  margin-top: 100px;
  margin-bottom: 100px;
  margin-right: 150px;
  margin-left: 80px;
}`

If the margin property has four values:
##Example:
`margin: 25px 50px 75px 100px;`
    ->top margin is 25px
    ->right margin is 50px
    ->bottom margin is 75px
    ->left margin is 100px

##Result:
$.\assets\images\css6.png

css.title: CSS Padding
css.content: In this lesson, you'll learn about CSS padding, which is used to create space around an element's content, inside of any defined borders.
css.lesson:
Padding is used to create space around an element's content, inside of any defined borders.
To shorten the code, it is possible to specify all the padding properties in one property.
The padding property is a shorthand property for the following individual padding properties:
1. padding-top
2. padding-right
3. padding-bottom
4. padding-left

So, here is how it works:
If the padding property has four values,
padding: 25px 50px 75px 100px;
      -> top padding is 25px
      -> right padding is 50px
      -> bottom padding is 75px
      -> left padding is 100px
##Example:
`div {
  padding: 25px 50px 75px 100px;
}`
##Result:
$.\assets\images\css7.png

css.title: CSS Height/Width
css.content: By the end of this lesson, you will understand how to use CSS properties to control the dimensions of HTML elements.
css.lesson:
#CSS Height and Width:
The height and width properties in CSS are used to set the height and width of an element.
These properties determine the size of the content area inside the padding, border, and margin of an element.
They can be set using different units like pixels (px), percentages (%), or other length units (e.g., cm).
##Example:
`div {
  height: 200px;
  width: 50%;
}`
In this example, a <div> element is styled with a height of 200 pixels and a width of 50% of its containing block.

#CSS Max-Width:
The max-width property is used to set the maximum width that an element can have.
It prevents an element from exceeding a certain width, even if the content inside it requires more space.
Max-width can be specified in length units (like pixels) or as a percentage of its containing block.
##Example:
`div {
  max-width: 500px;
  height: 100px;
}`
Here, a <div> element is styled with a maximum width of 500 pixels and a height of 100 pixels.

#Differences Between Width and Max-Width:
If both width and max-width are applied to the same element and the width value exceeds the max-width value, the max-width property will be used, and the width property will be ignored.
Max-width is particularly useful for ensuring that elements don't overflow their containers, especially on smaller screens or when the content dynamically changes size.

#Summary:
-> CSS offers properties like height, width, and max-width to control the dimensions of HTML elements.
-> Height and width determine the size of the content area inside an element.
-> Max-width sets the maximum width an element can have, preventing it from exceeding a certain size.

python.title: Python Syntax
python.content:
#Python Syntax
##Python syntax is designed to be clear and concise, making it easy to write and understand code. Statements are typically written on separate lines, and indentation is used to indicate code blocks.
python.lesson:
##Python Indentation
Indentation refers to the spaces at the beginning of a code line.

Where in other programming languages the indentation in code is for readability only, the indentation in Python is very important.

Python uses indentation to indicate a block of code.
The number of spaces is up to you as a programmer, the most common use is four, but it has to be at least one.
You have to use the same number of spaces in the same block of code, otherwise Python will give you an error
##Comments
Python has commenting capability for the purpose of in-code documentation.
`if 5 > 2:
 print("Five is greater than two!") 
if 5 > 2:
        print("Five is greater than two!")`

Comments start with a #, and Python will render the rest of the line as a comment:
`#This is a comment.
print("Hello, World!")`
#Python Variables
In Python, variables are created when you assign a value to it:
`x = 5
y = "Hello, World!"`
#Python has no command for declaring a variable.
#You will learn more about variables in the Python Variables chapter.

quiz.question: How do we denote a multi-line block of code in Python?
What symbol do we use to indicate comments in Python?

python.title: Python Variables
python.content:
#Python Variables
##Variables are used to store data values in Python. They are assigned using the equals sign (=) and can hold different types of data, such as numbers, strings, or booleans.
python.lesson:
#Variables are containers for storing data values.
##Creating Variables
Python has no command for declaring a variable.
A variable is created the moment you first assign a value to it.
`x = 5
y = "John"
print(x)
print(y)`
Variables do not need to be declared with any particular type, and can even change type after they have been set.
##If you want to specify the data type of a variable, this can be done with casting.
`x = str(3)    # x will be '3'
y = int(3)    # y will be 3
z = float(3)  # z will be 3.0`
##Get the Type
You can get the data type of a variable with the type() function.
`x = 5
y = "John"
print(type(x))
print(type(y))`
##Single or Double Quotes?
String variables can be declared either by using single or double quotes:
`x = "John"
# is the same as
x = 'John'`

python.title: Python Operators
python.content:
#Python Operators
##Operators are symbols used to perform operations on variables and values. Python supports various types of operators, including arithmetic, comparison, logical, and assignment operators.
python.lesson:
##Operators are used to perform operations on variables and values.

In the example below, we use the + operator to add together two values:
`print(10 + 5)`

Python divides the operators in the following groups:

-Arithmetic operators
-Assignment operators
-Comparison operators
-Logical operators
-Identity operators
-Membership operators
-Bitwise operators
`# Arithmetic operators
x = 5 + 3
y = 5 * 3
z = 5 / 2
# Comparison operators
a = 5 > 2
b = 5 == 2
c = 5 != 2
# Logical operators
p = True and False
q = True or False
# Assignment operators
x += 1  # Equivalent to x = x + 1`
##Python Comparison Operators
==	Equal	x == y	
!=	Not equal	x != y	
>	Greater than	x > y	
<	Less than	x < y	
>=	Greater than or equal to	x >= y	
<=	Less than or equal to	x <= y
##Python Arithmetic Operators
+	Addition	x + y	
-	Subtraction	x - y	
*	Multiplication	x * y	
/	Division	x / y	
%	Modulus	x % y	
**	Exponentiation	x ** y	
//	Floor division	x // y
##Python Bitwise Operators
& 	AND	Sets each bit to 1 if both bits are 1	x & y	
|	OR	Sets each bit to 1 if one of two bits is 1	x | y	
^	XOR	Sets each bit to 1 if only one of two bits is 1	x ^ y	
~	NOT	Inverts all the bits	~x	
<<	Zero fill left shift	Shift left by pushing zeros in from the right and let the leftmost bits fall off	x << 2	
>>	Signed right shift	Shift right by pushing copies of the leftmost bit in from the left, and let the rightmost bits fall off	x >> 2
##Operator Precedence
`print((6 + 3) - (6 + 3))`
Parentheses has the highest precedence, meaning that expressions inside parentheses must be evaluated first:
Multiplication * has higher precedence than addition +, and therefor multiplications are evaluated before additions:
`print(100 + 5 * 3)`
#The precedence order is described in the table below, starting with the highest precedence at the top:

()	Parentheses	
**	Exponentiation	
+x  -x  ~x	Unary plus, unary minus, and bitwise NOT	
*  /  //  %	Multiplication, division, floor division, and modulus	
+  -	Addition and subtraction	
<<  >>	Bitwise left and right shifts	
&	Bitwise AND	
^	Bitwise XOR	
|	Bitwise OR	
==  !=  >  >=  <  <=  is  is not  in  not in 	Comparisons, identity, and membership operators	
not	Logical NOT	
and	AND	
or	OR

python.title: Python Lists, Tuples, Sets
python.content:
#Python Lists, Tuples, Sets
##Lists, tuples, and sets are data structures used to store collections of items in Python. Lists are mutable, ordered collections, while tuples are immutable. Sets are unordered collections with no duplicate elements.
python.lesson:
`# List
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
# Tuple
colors = ("red", "green", "blue")
# Set
numbers = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}`
##List
Lists are used to store multiple items in a single variable.

Lists are one of 4 built-in data types in Python used to store collections of data, the other 3 are Tuple, Set, and Dictionary, all with different qualities and usage.

Lists are created using square brackets:
`thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(thislist)`
##List Items
List items are ordered, changeable, and allow duplicate values.

List items are indexed, the first item has index [0], the second item has index [1] etc.
##Ordered
When we say that lists are ordered, it means that the items have a defined order, and that order will not change.

If you add new items to a list, the new items will be placed at the end of the list.
##Allow Duplicates
Since lists are indexed, lists can have items with the same value:
`thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "apple", "cherry"]
print(thislist)`
##List Length
`thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(len(thislist))`

quiz.question: Which data type in Python is ordered and mutable?
What is the correct syntax for creating a tuple?

python.title: Python Dictionaries
python.content:
#Python Dictionaries
##Dictionaries are data structures used to store key-value pairs in Python. Each key is associated with a value, allowing for efficient lookup and retrieval of data.
##Use dictionaries to store and retrieve data in key-value pairs. Dictionaries are useful for representing structured data and organizing information in your programs.
python.lesson:
##Dictionaries are used to store data values in key:value pairs.

A dictionary is a collection which is ordered*, changeable and do not allow duplicates.
`thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
print(thisdict)`
##Dictionary Items
Dictionary items are ordered, changeable, and do not allow duplicates.

Dictionary items are presented in key:value pairs, and can be referred to by using the key name.
`thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
print(thisdict["brand"])`
##Ordered or Unordered?
When we say that dictionaries are ordered, it means that the items have a defined order, and that order will not change.

Unordered means that the items do not have a defined order, you cannot refer to an item by using an index.
##Changeable
Dictionaries are changeable, meaning that we can change, add or remove items after the dictionary has been created.
##Duplicates Not Allowed
Dictionaries cannot have two items with the same key:

`thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964,
  "year": 2020
}
print(thisdict)`

quiz.question: How are items stored in a dictionary?
What happens if you try to access a key that does not exist in a dictionary?

python.title: Python If…Else
python.content:
#Python If…Else
## If...else statements are used to make decisions in Python based on certain conditions. They allow your program to execute different code blocks depending on whether a condition is true or false.
##Use if...else statements to control the flow of your program and perform different actions based on specific conditions. They are essential for implementing logic and making your programs more dynamic.
python.lesson:
#Python Conditions and If statements
Python supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:
Equals: a == b
Not Equals: a != b
Less than: a < b
Less than or equal to: a <= b
Greater than: a > b
Greater than or equal to: a >= b
`Example:
x = 5
if x > 3:
    print("x is greater than 3")
else:
    print("x is less than or equal to 3")`
#Indentation
Python relies on indentation (whitespace at the beginning of a line) to define scope in the code. Other programming languages often use curly-brackets for this purpose.

##Elif
The elif keyword is Python's way of saying "if the previous conditions were not true, then try this condition".
`a = 33
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
elif a == b:
  print("a and b are equal")`

##Else
The else keyword catches anything which isn't caught by the preceding conditions.
`a = 200
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
elif a == b:
  print("a and b are equal")
else:
  print("a is greater than b")`

In this example a is greater than b, so the first condition is not true, also the elif condition is not true, so we go to the else condition and print to screen that "a is greater than b".

You can also have an else without the elif:

`a = 200
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
else:
  print("b is not greater than a")`


##Short Hand If
If you have only one statement to execute, you can put it on the same line as the if statement.
`if a > b: print("a is greater than b")`

##And
The and keyword is a logical operator, and is used to combine conditional statements:
`a = 200
b = 33
c = 500
if a > b and c > a:
  print("Both conditions are True")`
##Or
The or keyword is a logical operator, and is used to combine conditional statements:
`a = 200
b = 33
c = 500
if a > b or a > c:
  print("At least one of the conditions is True")`

##Not
The not keyword is a logical operator, and is used to reverse the result of the conditional statement:
`a = 33
b = 200
if not a > b:
  print("a is NOT greater than b")`

#Nested If
You can have if statements inside if statements, this is called nested if statements.
`x = 41

if x > 10:
  print("Above ten,")
  if x > 20:
    print("and also above 20!")
  else:
    print("but not above 20.")`

quiz.question: What keyword is used to start an if statement in Python?
What happens if no conditions in an if...elif...else statement are True?

python.title: Python While Loops
python.content:
#Python While Loops
## While loops are used to execute a block of code repeatedly as long as a specified condition is true. They continue iterating until the condition becomes false.
##Use while loops when you need to repeatedly execute a block of code until a certain condition is met. Be cautious to avoid infinite loops by ensuring that the condition eventually becomes false.
python.lesson:
`Example:
i = 0
while i < 5:
    print(i)
    i += 1`

##Python Loops
Python has two primitive loop commands:

while loops
for loops

##The break Statement
With the break statement we can stop the loop even if the while condition is true:
`i = 1
while i < 6:
  print(i)
  if i == 3:
    break
  i += 1`

##The continue Statement
`i = 0
while i < 6:
  i += 1
  if i == 3:
    continue
  print(i)`


##The else Statement
With the else statement we can run a block of code once when the condition no longer is true:
`i = 1
while i < 6:
  print(i)
  i += 1
else:
  print("i is no longer less than 6")`

quiz.question: What keyword is used to start a while loop in Python?
How do you exit a while loop prematurely?

html.title: Основы HTML
html.content:
# Введение
HTML, основа веб-разработки, является языком разметки, используемым для структурирования и представления контента в Интернете. Он использует теги, заключенные в угловые скобки, для определения элементов в документе.

## Понимание тегов и элементов
Теги являются строительными блоками HTML, представляя элементы, такие как заголовки, абзацы, изображения и ссылки. Каждый тег служит определенной цели в форматировании и организации контента.

## Структура базового HTML-документа
Типичный HTML-документ начинается с объявления типа документа (`<!DOCTYPE html>`), за которым следует элемент HTML (`<html>`), который содержит структуру документа внутри секций `<head>` и `<body>`.

html.title: Ссылки и якоря
html.content:
# Создание гиперссылок
Гиперссылки необходимы для соединения веб-страниц. Они создаются с использованием тега `<a>` (якоря), а атрибут `href` указывает URL связанной страницы.

## Ссылки на внешние веб-сайты
Для создания ссылок на внешние веб-сайты атрибут `href` содержит полный URL страницы назначения. Пользователи могут нажимать на эти ссылки для перехода на указанный веб-сайт.

## Теги якорей и внутренние ссылки
Теги якорей также могут использоваться для создания внутренних ссылок внутри одной и той же веб-страницы. Это достигается путем установки атрибута `href` на ID другого элемента на странице, позволяя пользователям переходить к конкретному разделу.

Они добавляются на веб-страницы с помощью тегов `

html.title: Списки в HTML
html.content:
# Нумерованные списки
Нумерованные списки (`<ol>`) используются для элементов с определенной последовательностью или порядком. Каждый элемент списка (`<li>`) автоматически нумеруется браузером.

## Ненумерованные списки
Ненумерованные списки (`<ul>`) используются для элементов без определенного порядка. Для обозначения каждого элемента списка (`<li>`) используются маркеры или другие метки.

## Списки определений
Списки определений (`<dl>`) состоят из терминов (`<dt>`) и их определений (`<dd>`). Они часто используются для глоссариев или словарей.

html.title: Таблицы в HTML
html.content:
# Создание таблиц
Таблицы структурируются с использованием тега `<table>`, строки определяются тегами `<tr>`, а ячейки в каждой строке определяются тегами `<td>`.

## Строки и столбцы таблицы
Строки (`<tr>`) и столбцы (`<td>`) формируют основную структуру таблицы. Дополнительные теги, такие как `<th>`, используются для заголовков таблицы для указания заголовков столбцов.

## Заголовки и подвалы таблицы
Заголовки таблицы (`<th>`) могут использоваться для определения заголовков строк или столбцов, а тег `<tfoot>` указывает подвал для таблицы.

html.title: Формы и поля ввода
html.content:
# Создание HTML-форм
Формы создаются с использованием тега `<form>`, который содержит различные элементы ввода, такие как текстовые поля, флажки, переключатели и раскрывающиеся меню.

## Элементы ввода формы
Элементы ввода собирают данные пользователя. Среди них текстовые поля (`<input type="text">`), флажки (`<input type="checkbox">`), переключатели (`<input type="radio">`) и раскрывающиеся меню (`<select>`).

## Отправка данных формы
Данные формы отправляются на сервер для обработки с использованием атрибута `action` тега `<form>`, который указывает URL, куда должны быть отправлены данные формы.

html.title: Семантический HTML
html.content:
# Введение в семантические элементы
Семантические элементы HTML придают значение контенту не только представлением. Они включают элементы, такие как `<header>`, `<footer>`, `<nav>`, `<article>`, `<section>` и `<aside>`.

## Элементы заголовка и подвала
`<header>` и `<footer>` определяют верхнюю и нижнюю части веб-страницы соответственно. Они обычно содержат ссылки навигации, информацию о копирайте и другие метаданные.

## Элементы разделения
Элементы разделения, такие как `<section>`, `<article>`, `<nav>` и `<aside>`, используются для разделения содержимого веб-страницы на значимые разделы, улучшая доступность и SEO.

html.title: Возможности HTML5
html.content:
# Введение в HTML5
HTML5 вводит новые функции и элементы для современной веб-разработки, включая поддержку мультимедиа, семантические элементы и улучшенные формы и API.

## Графика Canvas и SVG
Элемент `<canvas>` позволяет динамическое отображение графики с использованием JavaScript, а SVG (масштабируемая векторная графика) обеспечивает изображения и анимации с разрешением, независимым от разрешения экрана.

## Воспроизведение аудио и видео
HTML5 вводит нативную поддержку воспроизведения аудио и видео с использованием элементов `<audio>` и `<video>`. Это устраняет необходимость в сторонних плагинах, таких как Flash.

html.title: HTML Basics
html.content:
##Welcome to the HTML Basics lesson! In this lesson, we'll cover the essential elements of HTML to get you started on your web development journey.

HTML, which stands for HyperText Markup Language, is the standard language used to create and design web pages.
In this lesson, you'll discover:

1. The purpose and usage of the DOCTYPE declaration.
2. Basic HTML structure and elements.
3. How to view the HTML source code of a web page.
html.lesson:
##Understanding the DOCTYPE Declaration

The DOCTYPE declaration is an essential part of an HTML document. It specifies the version of HTML being used and helps web browsers render the page correctly. Here's an example of the DOCTYPE declaration for HTML5:

`<!DOCTYPE html>`

This declaration should be placed at the beginning of every HTML document to ensure compatibility and proper rendering.

##Basic HTML Structure

An HTML document consists of several basic elements, including:

1. <html>: This tag marks the beginning and end of your webpage. All other elements are placed inside it. It should always be closed at the end of the document, like this <\html>.

2. <head>: Within this tag, you include important information about your webpage, like its title, keywords, and references to other files.  It should be closed -<\head>- before the <body> tag starts.

3. <body>: Inside this tag, you put all the content that users see when they visit your webpage, like text, images, and links. It should be closed at the end of the document - <\body>.

4. <title>: This tag sets the title of your webpage, which appears at the top of the browser window or tab. It's self-contained within the <head> section.

5. <meta>: These tags provide additional information about your webpage, such as its character encoding and viewport settings. They are self-closing tags and do not require a separate closing tag.

##Viewing HTML Source Code

Ever stumbled upon a webpage that made you go, "Wow, how did they do that?" Let's unlock the mystery!
View HTML Source Code:
Click CTRL + U in an HTML page, or right-click on the page and select "View Page Source". This will open a new tab containing the HTML source code of the page.

html.title: HTML Elements and Attributes
html.content:
##1. The essence of HTML elements and their significance in web design.
##2. Understanding the syntax of HTML elements and the role of attributes in providing additional information about elements.
##3. Exploring various attributes and HTML elements in action.
html.lesson:
##Elements syntax unveiled: HTML utilizes elements as its core components. An HTML element is comprised of three main parts: 1. Start tag: It marks the beginning of an element and is enclosed within angle brackets (< and >). For instance, . 2. Element content: This is the actual content encapsulated by the element. It could be text, images, or other elements. 3. End tag: It denotes the conclusion of an element and is similar to the start tag, except it includes a forward slash before the tag name. For example, . Additionally, some elements may be empty, meaning they don't contain any content and thus don't require an end tag. These are known as empty elements. ##Elements in Action: Let's explore some examples to better grasp how HTML elements function: `

My First Heading

This is a
paragraph with a line break.

` In this example, you can see already familiar elements such as , , and . You'll also encounter an empty element,
, which represents a line break and is an empty element. Empty elements like
don't have a closing tag because they don't contain any content. ##Attributes HTML attributes provide additional information about elements and are always specified within the start tag of an element. 1. The href attribute is commonly used with the tag to define hyperlinks. It specifies the URL of the page the link goes to. For example: `Visit Example` 2. The src attribute is utilized with the tag to embed images in HTML pages. It specifies the path to the image to be displayed. ` ` 3. The width and height attributes define the width and height of an image in pixels, ensuring proper display. `` 4. The alt attribute provides alternate text for images, which is displayed if the image cannot be loaded. `` 5. The style attribute adds inline styles to elements, allowing customization of appearance. `

Styled paragraph

html.title: Your First HTML Paragraph
html.content:
##By now, you've gained a solid understanding of HTML basics and elements, including attributes. In this lesson, we'll put that knowledge into practice by creating your first paragraph in HTML.
##Recap of What You've Learned:

1. You've learned about the essential elements of HTML, such as <html>, <head>, <body>, <title>, and <meta>.
2. You've discovered the significance of the DOCTYPE declaration in specifying the HTML version and ensuring proper rendering.
3. You've explored HTML elements and their syntax, including start tags, element content, and end tags.
4. You've delved into the role of attributes in providing additional information about elements, and you've seen various attributes commonly used in HTML elements.
##Now, let's apply this knowledge to create your first paragraph in HTML!
html.lesson:
##Creating Your First Paragraph: To create a paragraph in HTML, we use the

element. This element allows us to structure text content into paragraphs on our web page. Here's a simple example of how to create your first paragraph in HTML: ` My First Web Page

Welcome to My Web Page!

This is my first paragraph in HTML. I'm learning how to create web pages, and it's exciting!

` In this example: 1. We've started with the DOCTYPE declaration () to specify the HTML version. 2. Inside the element, we've included the section, where we've set the title of our web page using the element. 3. The <body> element contains the visible content of our web page. We've added an <h1> element for the main heading (don’t panic! you will learn about headings in the subsequent lessons) and a <p> element for our paragraph. Feel free to customize the content of the paragraph to reflect your own thoughts, ideas, or any information you'd like to share on your web page. ##Congratulations! You've successfully created your first paragraph in HTML. Keep practicing and exploring new elements and attributes to enhance your web development skills.

css.title: CSS Selectors
css.content: In this lesson you will learn about selectors and how to operate with them.
css.lesson:
CSS selectors are used to "find" (or select) the HTML elements you want to style.

We can divide CSS selectors into five categories:
1) Simple selectors (select elements based on name, id, class)
2) Combinator selectors (select elements based on a specific relationship between them)
3) Pseudo-class selectors (select elements based on a certain state)
4) Pseudo-elements selectors (select and style a part of an element)
5) Attribute selectors (select elements based on an attribute or attribute value)

#The CSS id Selector
To select an element with a specific id, write a hash (#) character, followed by the id of the element.

##Example:
`#para1 {
  text-align: center;
  color: red;
}`

##Result:
$ Website\assets\images\css1.png

css.title: CSS Margins
css.content: In this lesson, you'll learn how to use CSS margin properties to create space around elements.
css.lesson:
Margins are used to create space around elements, outside of any defined borders.

CSS has properties for specifying the margin for each side of an element:
1. margin-top
2. margin-right
3. margin-bottom
5. margin-left
All the margin properties can have the following values:
1. auto - the browser calculates the margin
2. length - specifies a margin in px, pt, cm, etc.
3. % - specifies a margin in % of the width of the containing element
4. inherit - specifies that the margin should be inherited from the parent element
##Example:
`p {
  margin-top: 100px;
  margin-bottom: 100px;
  margin-right: 150px;
  margin-left: 80px;
}`

If the margin property has four values:
##Example:
`margin: 25px 50px 75px 100px;`
    ->top margin is 25px
    ->right margin is 50px
    ->bottom margin is 75px
    ->left margin is 100px

##Result:
$.\assets\images\css6.png

To set the font size of elements

options: It sets the margin to a fixed length

It sets the margin to a percentage value

css.title: CSS Padding
css.content: In this lesson, you'll learn about CSS padding, which is used to create space around an element's content, inside of any defined borders.
css.lesson:
Padding is used to create space around an element's content, inside of any defined borders.
To shorten the code, it is possible to specify all the padding properties in one property.
The padding property is a shorthand property for the following individual padding properties:
1. padding-top
2. padding-right
3. padding-bottom
4. padding-left

So, here is how it works:
If the padding property has four values,
padding: 25px 50px 75px 100px;
      -> top padding is 25px
      -> right padding is 50px
      -> bottom padding is 75px
      -> left padding is 100px
##Example:
`div {
  padding: 25px 50px 75px 100px;
}`
##Result:
$.\assets\images\css7.png

css.title: CSS Height/Width
css.content: By the end of this lesson, you will understand how to use CSS properties to control the dimensions of HTML elements.
css.lesson:
#CSS Height and Width:
The height and width properties in CSS are used to set the height and width of an element.
These properties determine the size of the content area inside the padding, border, and margin of an element.
They can be set using different units like pixels (px), percentages (%), or other length units (e.g., cm).
##Example:
`div {
  height: 200px;
  width: 50%;
}`
In this example, a <div> element is styled with a height of 200 pixels and a width of 50% of its containing block.

#CSS Max-Width:
The max-width property is used to set the maximum width that an element can have.
It prevents an element from exceeding a certain width, even if the content inside it requires more space.
Max-width can be specified in length units (like pixels) or as a percentage of its containing block.
##Example:
`div {
  max-width: 500px;
  height: 100px;
}`
Here, a <div> element is styled with a maximum width of 500 pixels and a height of 100 pixels.

#Differences Between Width and Max-Width:
If both width and max-width are applied to the same element and the width value exceeds the max-width value, the max-width property will be used, and the width property will be ignored.
Max-width is particularly useful for ensuring that elements don't overflow their containers, especially on smaller screens or when the content dynamically changes size.

#Summary:
-> CSS offers properties like height, width, and max-width to control the dimensions of HTML elements.
-> Height and width determine the size of the content area inside an element.
-> Max-width sets the maximum width an element can have, preventing it from exceeding a certain size.

##Python Indentation
Indentation refers to the spaces at the beginning of a code line.

Where in other programming languages the indentation in code is for readability only, the indentation in Python is very important.

Python uses indentation to indicate a block of code.
The number of spaces is up to you as a programmer, the most common use is four, but it has to be at least one.
You have to use the same number of spaces in the same block of code, otherwise Python will give you an error
##Comments
Python has commenting capability for the purpose of in-code documentation.
`if 5 > 2:
 print("Five is greater than two!") 
if 5 > 2:
        print("Five is greater than two!")`

Comments start with a #, and Python will render the rest of the line as a comment:
`#This is a comment.
print("Hello, World!")`
#Python Variables
In Python, variables are created when you assign a value to it:
`x = 5
y = "Hello, World!"`
#Python has no command for declaring a variable.
#You will learn more about variables in the Python Variables chapter.

quiz.question: How do we denote a multi-line block of code in Python?
What symbol do we use to indicate comments in Python?

python.title: Python Variables
python.content:
#Python Variables
##Variables are used to store data values in Python. They are assigned using the equals sign (=) and can hold different types of data, such as numbers, strings, or booleans.
python.lesson:
#Variables are containers for storing data values.
##Creating Variables
Python has no command for declaring a variable.
A variable is created the moment you first assign a value to it.
`x = 5
y = "John"
print(x)
print(y)`
Variables do not need to be declared with any particular type, and can even change type after they have been set.
##If you want to specify the data type of a variable, this can be done with casting.
`x = str(3)    # x will be '3'
y = int(3)    # y will be 3
z = float(3)  # z will be 3.0`
##Get the Type
You can get the data type of a variable with the type() function.
`x = 5
y = "John"
print(type(x))
print(type(y))`
##Single or Double Quotes?
String variables can be declared either by using single or double quotes:
`x = "John"
# is the same as
x = 'John'`

python.title: Python Operators
python.content:
#Python Operators
##Operators are symbols used to perform operations on variables and values. Python supports various types of operators, including arithmetic, comparison, logical, and assignment operators.
python.lesson:
##Operators are used to perform operations on variables and values.

In the example below, we use the + operator to add together two values:
`print(10 + 5)`

Python divides the operators in the following groups:

-Arithmetic operators
-Assignment operators
-Comparison operators
-Logical operators
-Identity operators
-Membership operators
-Bitwise operators
`# Arithmetic operators
x = 5 + 3
y = 5 * 3
z = 5 / 2
# Comparison operators
a = 5 > 2
b = 5 == 2
c = 5 != 2
# Logical operators
p = True and False
q = True or False
# Assignment operators
x += 1  # Equivalent to x = x + 1`
##Python Comparison Operators
==	Equal	x == y	
!=	Not equal	x != y	
>	Greater than	x > y	
<	Less than	x < y	
>=	Greater than or equal to	x >= y	
<=	Less than or equal to	x <= y
##Python Arithmetic Operators
+	Addition	x + y	
-	Subtraction	x - y	
*	Multiplication	x * y	
/	Division	x / y	
%	Modulus	x % y	
**	Exponentiation	x ** y	
//	Floor division	x // y
##Python Bitwise Operators
& 	AND	Sets each bit to 1 if both bits are 1	x & y	
|	OR	Sets each bit to 1 if one of two bits is 1	x | y	
^	XOR	Sets each bit to 1 if only one of two bits is 1	x ^ y	
~	NOT	Inverts all the bits	~x	
<<	Zero fill left shift	Shift left by pushing zeros in from the right and let the leftmost bits fall off	x << 2	
>>	Signed right shift	Shift right by pushing copies of the leftmost bit in from the left, and let the rightmost bits fall off	x >> 2
##Operator Precedence
`print((6 + 3) - (6 + 3))`
Parentheses has the highest precedence, meaning that expressions inside parentheses must be evaluated first:
Multiplication * has higher precedence than addition +, and therefor multiplications are evaluated before additions:
`print(100 + 5 * 3)`
#The precedence order is described in the table below, starting with the highest precedence at the top:

()	Parentheses	
**	Exponentiation	
+x  -x  ~x	Unary plus, unary minus, and bitwise NOT	
*  /  //  %	Multiplication, division, floor division, and modulus	
+  -	Addition and subtraction	
<<  >>	Bitwise left and right shifts	
&	Bitwise AND	
^	Bitwise XOR	
|	Bitwise OR	
==  !=  >  >=  <  <=  is  is not  in  not in 	Comparisons, identity, and membership operators	
not	Logical NOT	
and	AND	
or	OR

What operator is used for exponentiation in Python?

python.title: Python Lists, Tuples, Sets
python.content:
#Python Lists, Tuples, Sets
##Lists, tuples, and sets are data structures used to store collections of items in Python. Lists are mutable, ordered collections, while tuples are immutable. Sets are unordered collections with no duplicate elements.
python.lesson:
`# List
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
# Tuple
colors = ("red", "green", "blue")
# Set
numbers = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}`
##List
Lists are used to store multiple items in a single variable.

Lists are one of 4 built-in data types in Python used to store collections of data, the other 3 are Tuple, Set, and Dictionary, all with different qualities and usage.

Lists are created using square brackets:
`thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(thislist)`
##List Items
List items are ordered, changeable, and allow duplicate values.

List items are indexed, the first item has index [0], the second item has index [1] etc.
##Ordered
When we say that lists are ordered, it means that the items have a defined order, and that order will not change.

If you add new items to a list, the new items will be placed at the end of the list.
##Allow Duplicates
Since lists are indexed, lists can have items with the same value:
`thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "apple", "cherry"]
print(thislist)`
##List Length
`thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(len(thislist))`

quiz.question: Which data type in Python is ordered and mutable?
What is the correct syntax for creating a tuple?

python.title: Python Dictionaries
python.content:
#Python Dictionaries
##Dictionaries are data structures used to store key-value pairs in Python. Each key is associated with a value, allowing for efficient lookup and retrieval of data.
##Use dictionaries to store and retrieve data in key-value pairs. Dictionaries are useful for representing structured data and organizing information in your programs.
python.lesson:
##Dictionaries are used to store data values in key:value pairs.

A dictionary is a collection which is ordered*, changeable and do not allow duplicates.
`thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
print(thisdict)`
##Dictionary Items
Dictionary items are ordered, changeable, and do not allow duplicates.

Dictionary items are presented in key:value pairs, and can be referred to by using the key name.
`thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
print(thisdict["brand"])`
##Ordered or Unordered?
When we say that dictionaries are ordered, it means that the items have a defined order, and that order will not change.

Unordered means that the items do not have a defined order, you cannot refer to an item by using an index.
##Changeable
Dictionaries are changeable, meaning that we can change, add or remove items after the dictionary has been created.
##Duplicates Not Allowed
Dictionaries cannot have two items with the same key:

`thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964,
  "year": 2020
}
print(thisdict)`

quiz.question: How are items stored in a dictionary?
What happens if you try to access a key that does not exist in a dictionary?

python.title: Python If…Else
python.content:
#Python If…Else
## If...else statements are used to make decisions in Python based on certain conditions. They allow your program to execute different code blocks depending on whether a condition is true or false.
##Use if...else statements to control the flow of your program and perform different actions based on specific conditions. They are essential for implementing logic and making your programs more dynamic.
python.lesson:
#Python Conditions and If statements
Python supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:
Equals: a == b
Not Equals: a != b
Less than: a < b
Less than or equal to: a <= b
Greater than: a > b
Greater than or equal to: a >= b
`Example:
x = 5
if x > 3:
    print("x is greater than 3")
else:
    print("x is less than or equal to 3")`
#Indentation
Python relies on indentation (whitespace at the beginning of a line) to define scope in the code. Other programming languages often use curly-brackets for this purpose.

##Elif
The elif keyword is Python's way of saying "if the previous conditions were not true, then try this condition".
`a = 33
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
elif a == b:
  print("a and b are equal")`

##Else
The else keyword catches anything which isn't caught by the preceding conditions.
`a = 200
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
elif a == b:
  print("a and b are equal")
else:
  print("a is greater than b")`

In this example a is greater than b, so the first condition is not true, also the elif condition is not true, so we go to the else condition and print to screen that "a is greater than b".

You can also have an else without the elif:

`a = 200
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
else:
  print("b is not greater than a")`


##Short Hand If
If you have only one statement to execute, you can put it on the same line as the if statement.
`if a > b: print("a is greater than b")`

##And
The and keyword is a logical operator, and is used to combine conditional statements:
`a = 200
b = 33
c = 500
if a > b and c > a:
  print("Both conditions are True")`
##Or
The or keyword is a logical operator, and is used to combine conditional statements:
`a = 200
b = 33
c = 500
if a > b or a > c:
  print("At least one of the conditions is True")`

##Not
The not keyword is a logical operator, and is used to reverse the result of the conditional statement:
`a = 33
b = 200
if not a > b:
  print("a is NOT greater than b")`

#Nested If
You can have if statements inside if statements, this is called nested if statements.
`x = 41

if x > 10:
  print("Above ten,")
  if x > 20:
    print("and also above 20!")
  else:
    print("but not above 20.")`

quiz.question: What keyword is used to start an if statement in Python?
What happens if no conditions in an if...elif...else statement are True?

python.title: Python While Loops
python.content:
#Python While Loops
## While loops are used to execute a block of code repeatedly as long as a specified condition is true. They continue iterating until the condition becomes false.
##Use while loops when you need to repeatedly execute a block of code until a certain condition is met. Be cautious to avoid infinite loops by ensuring that the condition eventually becomes false.
python.lesson:
`Example:
i = 0
while i < 5:
    print(i)
    i += 1`

##Python Loops
Python has two primitive loop commands:

while loops
for loops

##The break Statement
With the break statement we can stop the loop even if the while condition is true:
`i = 1
while i < 6:
  print(i)
  if i == 3:
    break
  i += 1`

##The continue Statement
`i = 0
while i < 6:
  i += 1
  if i == 3:
    continue
  print(i)`


##The else Statement
With the else statement we can run a block of code once when the condition no longer is true:
`i = 1
while i < 6:
  print(i)
  i += 1
else:
  print("i is no longer less than 6")`

quiz.question: What keyword is used to start a while loop in Python?
How do you exit a while loop prematurely?

# Introducere
HTML, coloana vertebrala a dezvoltarii web, este un limbaj de marcaj folosit pentru a structura si prezenta continutul pe internet. Foloseste taguri inchise in paranteze unghiulare pentru a defini elementele dintr-un document.

## Intelegerea Tagurilor si Elementelor
Tagurile sunt blocurile de constructie ale HTML-ului, reprezentand elemente precum antete, paragrafe, imagini si linkuri. Fiecare tag serveste un scop specific in formatarea si organizarea continutului.

## Structura de Baza a Documentului HTML
Un document HTML tipic incepe cu o declaratie de tip de document (`<!DOCTYPE html>`), urmata de un element HTML (`<html>`), care contine structura documentului in sectiunile `<head>` si `<body>`.

html.title: Linkuri si Ancore
html.content:
# Crearea Hiperlinkurilor
Hiperlinkurile sunt esentiale pentru conectarea paginilor web. Ele sunt create folosind tagul `<a>` (ancora), iar atributul `href` specifica URL-ul paginii legate.

## Linkuri catre Site-uri Externe
Pentru a face legatura catre site-uri externe, atributul `href` contine URL-ul complet al paginii de destinatie. Utilizatorii pot da clic pe aceste linkuri pentru a naviga la site-ul specificat.

## Tagurile Ancorelor si Linkuri Interne
Tagurile ancorelor pot fi, de asemenea, utilizate pentru a crea linkuri interne in aceeasi pagina web. Acest lucru se realizeaza setand atributul `href` la ID-ul altui element de pe pagina, permitand utilizatorilor sa sara la o sectiune specifica.

Atributul `src` specifica calea catre fisierul de imagine, in timp ce atributul `alt` furnizeaza text alternativ in scopuri de accesibilitate. ## Adaugarea Audio si Video Continutul audio si video poate imbunatati implicarea utilizatorului. Acestea sunt adaugate paginilor web folosind tagurile `

html.title: Liste in HTML
html.content:
# Liste Ordonate
Listele ordonate (`<ol>`) sunt folosite pentru elemente cu o secventa sau ordine specifica. Fiecare element al listei (`<li>`) este numerotat automat de catre browser.

## Liste Neordonate
Listele neordonate (`<ul>`) sunt folosite pentru elemente fara o ordine particulara. Bule sau alte marcaje sunt folosite pentru a indica fiecare element al listei (`<li>`).

## Liste de Definitii
Listele de definitii (`<dl>`) constau din termeni (`<dt>`) si definitiile lor (`<dd>`). Ele sunt folosite in mod obisnuit pentru glosare sau dictionare.

html.title: Tabele in HTML
html.content:
# Crearea Tabelului
Tabelele sunt structurate folosind tagul `<table>`, cu randuri definite de tagurile `<tr>` si celule in fiecare rand definite de tagurile `<td>`.

## Randuri si Coloane ale Tabelului
Randurile (`<tr>`) si coloanele (`<td>`) formeaza structura de baza a unui tabel. Taguri suplimentare precum `<th>` sunt folosite pentru antetele tabelului pentru a specifica titlurile de coloane.

## Antete si Subsoluri ale Tabelului
Antetele tabelului (`<th>`) pot fi folosite pentru a defini antetele pentru randuri sau coloane, in timp ce tagul `<tfoot>` specifica un subsol pentru un tabel.
html.lesson: # lectia ta va fi aici

html.title: Formulare si Intrari
html.content:
# Crearea Formularilor HTML
Formularele sunt create folosind tagul `<form>`, care contine diverse elemente de intrare cum ar fi campuri de text, casute de bifat, butoane radio si meniuri derulante.

## Elemente de Intrare ale Formularului
Elementele de intrare colecteaza date de la utilizator. Acestea includ campuri de text (`<input type="text">`), casete de bifat (`<input type="checkbox">`), butoane radio (`<input type="radio">`) si meniuri derulante (`<select>`).

## Trimiterea Datelor Formularului
Datele formularului sunt trimise unui server pentru procesare folosind atributul `action` al tagului `<form>`, care specifica URL-ul unde datele formularului ar trebui trimise.
html.lesson: # lectia ta va fi aici

html.title: HTML Semantic
html.content:
# Introducere in Elementele Semantice HTML
Elementele HTML semantice ofera semnificatie continutului in afara doar de prezentare. Ele includ elemente precum `<header>`, `<footer>`, `<nav>`, `<article>`, `<section>` si `<aside>`.

## Elemente de Antet si Subsol
`<header>` si `<footer>` definesc sectiunile superioare si inferioare ale unei pagini web, respectiv. Ele contin in mod obisnuit linkuri de navigare, informatii despre drepturile de autor si alte metadate.

## Elemente de Sectiune
Elementele de sectiune precum `<section>`, `<article>`, `<nav>` si `<aside>` sunt folosite pentru a impartasi continutul unei pagini web in sectiuni semnificative, imbunatatind accesibilitatea si SEO.
html.lesson: # lectia ta va fi aici

html.title: Caracteristici HTML5
html.content:
# Introducere in HTML5
HTML5 introduce noi caracteristici si elemente pentru dezvoltarea web moderna, inclusiv suport pentru multimedia, elemente semantice si forme si API-uri imbunatatite.

## Grafica Canvas si SVG
Elementul `<canvas>` permite redarea dinamica a graficii folosind JavaScript, in timp ce SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) ofera imagini si animatii independente de rezolutie.

## Redare Audio si Video
HTML5 introduce suport nativ pentru redarea audio si video folosind elementele `<audio>` si `<video>`. Acest lucru elimina necesitatea de pluginuri terte precum Flash.

html.title: HTML Basics
html.content:
##Welcome to the HTML Basics lesson! In this lesson, we'll cover the essential elements of HTML to get you started on your web development journey.

HTML, which stands for HyperText Markup Language, is the standard language used to create and design web pages.
In this lesson, you'll discover:

1. The purpose and usage of the DOCTYPE declaration.
2. Basic HTML structure and elements.
3. How to view the HTML source code of a web page.
html.lesson:
##Understanding the DOCTYPE Declaration

The DOCTYPE declaration is an essential part of an HTML document. It specifies the version of HTML being used and helps web browsers render the page correctly. Here's an example of the DOCTYPE declaration for HTML5:

`<!DOCTYPE html>`

This declaration should be placed at the beginning of every HTML document to ensure compatibility and proper rendering.

##Basic HTML Structure

An HTML document consists of several basic elements, including:

1. <html>: This tag marks the beginning and end of your webpage. All other elements are placed inside it. It should always be closed at the end of the document, like this <\html>.

2. <head>: Within this tag, you include important information about your webpage, like its title, keywords, and references to other files.  It should be closed -<\head>- before the <body> tag starts.

3. <body>: Inside this tag, you put all the content that users see when they visit your webpage, like text, images, and links. It should be closed at the end of the document - <\body>.

4. <title>: This tag sets the title of your webpage, which appears at the top of the browser window or tab. It's self-contained within the <head> section.

5. <meta>: These tags provide additional information about your webpage, such as its character encoding and viewport settings. They are self-closing tags and do not require a separate closing tag.

##Viewing HTML Source Code

Ever stumbled upon a webpage that made you go, "Wow, how did they do that?" Let's unlock the mystery!
View HTML Source Code:
Click CTRL + U in an HTML page, or right-click on the page and select "View Page Source". This will open a new tab containing the HTML source code of the page.

options: B) Right-click and select "View Page Source"

html.title: HTML Elements and Attributes
html.content:
##1. The essence of HTML elements and their significance in web design.
##2. Understanding the syntax of HTML elements and the role of attributes in providing additional information about elements.
##3. Exploring various attributes and HTML elements in action.
html.lesson:
##Elements syntax unveiled: HTML utilizes elements as its core components. An HTML element is comprised of three main parts: 1. Start tag: It marks the beginning of an element and is enclosed within angle brackets (< and >). For instance, . 2. Element content: This is the actual content encapsulated by the element. It could be text, images, or other elements. 3. End tag: It denotes the conclusion of an element and is similar to the start tag, except it includes a forward slash before the tag name. For example, . Additionally, some elements may be empty, meaning they don't contain any content and thus don't require an end tag. These are known as empty elements. ##Elements in Action: Let's explore some examples to better grasp how HTML elements function: `

My First Heading

This is a
paragraph with a line break.

` In this example, you can see already familiar elements such as , , and . You'll also encounter an empty element,
, which represents a line break and is an empty element. Empty elements like
don't have a closing tag because they don't contain any content. ##Attributes HTML attributes provide additional information about elements and are always specified within the start tag of an element. 1. The href attribute is commonly used with the tag to define hyperlinks. It specifies the URL of the page the link goes to. For example: `Visit Example` 2. The src attribute is utilized with the tag to embed images in HTML pages. It specifies the path to the image to be displayed. ` ` 3. The width and height attributes define the width and height of an image in pixels, ensuring proper display. `` 4. The alt attribute provides alternate text for images, which is displayed if the image cannot be loaded. `` 5. The style attribute adds inline styles to elements, allowing customization of appearance. `

Styled paragraph

` 6. The lang attribute specifies the language of the HTML document, assisting search engines and browsers. `` 7. The title attribute provides additional information about an element, displayed as a tooltip when hovered over. `

Hello

` ##Single or Double Quotes? Double quotes around attribute values are the most common in HTML, but single quotes can also be used. In some situations, when the attribute value itself contains double quotes, it is necessary to use single quotes: `

Hello

`

html.title: Your First HTML Paragraph
html.content:
##By now, you've gained a solid understanding of HTML basics and elements, including attributes. In this lesson, we'll put that knowledge into practice by creating your first paragraph in HTML.
##Recap of What You've Learned:

1. You've learned about the essential elements of HTML, such as <html>, <head>, <body>, <title>, and <meta>.
2. You've discovered the significance of the DOCTYPE declaration in specifying the HTML version and ensuring proper rendering.
3. You've explored HTML elements and their syntax, including start tags, element content, and end tags.
4. You've delved into the role of attributes in providing additional information about elements, and you've seen various attributes commonly used in HTML elements.
##Now, let's apply this knowledge to create your first paragraph in HTML!
html.lesson:
##Creating Your First Paragraph: To create a paragraph in HTML, we use the

element. This element allows us to structure text content into paragraphs on our web page. Here's a simple example of how to create your first paragraph in HTML: ` My First Web Page

Welcome to My Web Page!

This is my first paragraph in HTML. I'm learning how to create web pages, and it's exciting!

` In this example: 1. We've started with the DOCTYPE declaration () to specify the HTML version. 2. Inside the element, we've included the section, where we've set the title of our web page using the element. 3. The <body> element contains the visible content of our web page. We've added an <h1> element for the main heading (don’t panic! you will learn about headings in the subsequent lessons) and a <p> element for our paragraph. css.title: What is CSS?
css.content: Here you'll learn what CSS stands for.
css.lesson:
-> CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets.

-> CSS describes how HTML elements are to be described on screen, paper, or in other media.

-> CSS saves a lot of work. It can control the layout of multiple web pages all at once.

css.title: CSS Selectors
css.content: In this lesson you will learn about selectors and how to operate with them.
css.lesson:
CSS selectors are used to "find" (or select) the HTML elements you want to style.

We can divide CSS selectors into five categories:
1) Simple selectors (select elements based on name, id, class)
2) Combinator selectors (select elements based on a specific relationship between them)
3) Pseudo-class selectors (select elements based on a certain state)
4) Pseudo-elements selectors (select and style a part of an element)
5) Attribute selectors (select elements based on an attribute or attribute value)

#The CSS id Selector
To select an element with a specific id, write a hash (#) character, followed by the id of the element.

##Example:
`#para1 {
  text-align: center;
  color: red;
}`

##Result:
$ Website\assets\images\css1.png

css.title: CSS Margins
css.content: In this lesson, you'll learn how to use CSS margin properties to create space around elements.
css.lesson:
Margins are used to create space around elements, outside of any defined borders.

CSS has properties for specifying the margin for each side of an element:
1. margin-top
2. margin-right
3. margin-bottom
5. margin-left
All the margin properties can have the following values:
1. auto - the browser calculates the margin
2. length - specifies a margin in px, pt, cm, etc.
3. % - specifies a margin in % of the width of the containing element
4. inherit - specifies that the margin should be inherited from the parent element
##Example:
`p {
  margin-top: 100px;
  margin-bottom: 100px;
  margin-right: 150px;
  margin-left: 80px;
}`

If the margin property has four values:
##Example:
`margin: 25px 50px 75px 100px;`
    ->top margin is 25px
    ->right margin is 50px
    ->bottom margin is 75px
    ->left margin is 100px

##Result:
$.\assets\images\css6.png

To set the font size of elements

options: It sets the margin to a fixed length

It sets the margin to a percentage value

css.title: CSS Padding
css.content: In this lesson, you'll learn about CSS padding, which is used to create space around an element's content, inside of any defined borders.
css.lesson:
Padding is used to create space around an element's content, inside of any defined borders.
To shorten the code, it is possible to specify all the padding properties in one property.
The padding property is a shorthand property for the following individual padding properties:
1. padding-top
2. padding-right
3. padding-bottom
4. padding-left

So, here is how it works:
If the padding property has four values,
padding: 25px 50px 75px 100px;
      -> top padding is 25px
      -> right padding is 50px
      -> bottom padding is 75px
      -> left padding is 100px
##Example:
`div {
  padding: 25px 50px 75px 100px;
}`
##Result:
$.\assets\images\css7.png

css.title: CSS Height/Width
css.content: By the end of this lesson, you will understand how to use CSS properties to control the dimensions of HTML elements.
css.lesson:
#CSS Height and Width:
The height and width properties in CSS are used to set the height and width of an element.
These properties determine the size of the content area inside the padding, border, and margin of an element.
They can be set using different units like pixels (px), percentages (%), or other length units (e.g., cm).
##Example:
`div {
  height: 200px;
  width: 50%;
}`
In this example, a <div> element is styled with a height of 200 pixels and a width of 50% of its containing block.

#CSS Max-Width:
The max-width property is used to set the maximum width that an element can have.
It prevents an element from exceeding a certain width, even if the content inside it requires more space.
Max-width can be specified in length units (like pixels) or as a percentage of its containing block.
##Example:
`div {
  max-width: 500px;
  height: 100px;
}`
Here, a <div> element is styled with a maximum width of 500 pixels and a height of 100 pixels.

#Differences Between Width and Max-Width:
If both width and max-width are applied to the same element and the width value exceeds the max-width value, the max-width property will be used, and the width property will be ignored.
Max-width is particularly useful for ensuring that elements don't overflow their containers, especially on smaller screens or when the content dynamically changes size.

#Summary:
-> CSS offers properties like height, width, and max-width to control the dimensions of HTML elements.
-> Height and width determine the size of the content area inside an element.
-> Max-width sets the maximum width an element can have, preventing it from exceeding a certain size.

python.title: Python Syntax
python.content:
#Python Syntax
##Python syntax is designed to be clear and concise, making it easy to write and understand code. Statements are typically written on separate lines, and indentation is used to indicate code blocks.
python.lesson:
##Python Indentation
Indentation refers to the spaces at the beginning of a code line.

Where in other programming languages the indentation in code is for readability only, the indentation in Python is very important.

Python uses indentation to indicate a block of code.
The number of spaces is up to you as a programmer, the most common use is four, but it has to be at least one.
You have to use the same number of spaces in the same block of code, otherwise Python will give you an error
##Comments
Python has commenting capability for the purpose of in-code documentation.
`if 5 > 2:
 print("Five is greater than two!") 
if 5 > 2:
        print("Five is greater than two!")`

Comments start with a #, and Python will render the rest of the line as a comment:
`#This is a comment.
print("Hello, World!")`
#Python Variables
In Python, variables are created when you assign a value to it:
`x = 5
y = "Hello, World!"`
#Python has no command for declaring a variable.
#You will learn more about variables in the Python Variables chapter.

quiz.question: How do we denote a multi-line block of code in Python?
What symbol do we use to indicate comments in Python?

python.title: Python Variables
python.content:
#Python Variables
##Variables are used to store data values in Python. They are assigned using the equals sign (=) and can hold different types of data, such as numbers, strings, or booleans.
python.lesson:
#Variables are containers for storing data values.
##Creating Variables
Python has no command for declaring a variable.
A variable is created the moment you first assign a value to it.
`x = 5
y = "John"
print(x)
print(y)`
Variables do not need to be declared with any particular type, and can even change type after they have been set.
##If you want to specify the data type of a variable, this can be done with casting.
`x = str(3)    # x will be '3'
y = int(3)    # y will be 3
z = float(3)  # z will be 3.0`
##Get the Type
You can get the data type of a variable with the type() function.
`x = 5
y = "John"
print(type(x))
print(type(y))`
##Single or Double Quotes?
String variables can be declared either by using single or double quotes:
`x = "John"
# is the same as
x = 'John'`

What is the result of the following code snippet?(x = 5 y = "Hello" print(x + y))

python.title: Python Operators
python.content:
#Python Operators
##Operators are symbols used to perform operations on variables and values. Python supports various types of operators, including arithmetic, comparison, logical, and assignment operators.
python.lesson:
##Operators are used to perform operations on variables and values.

In the example below, we use the + operator to add together two values:
`print(10 + 5)`

Python divides the operators in the following groups:

-Arithmetic operators
-Assignment operators
-Comparison operators
-Logical operators
-Identity operators
-Membership operators
-Bitwise operators
`# Arithmetic operators
x = 5 + 3
y = 5 * 3
z = 5 / 2
# Comparison operators
a = 5 > 2
b = 5 == 2
c = 5 != 2
# Logical operators
p = True and False
q = True or False
# Assignment operators
x += 1  # Equivalent to x = x + 1`
##Python Comparison Operators
==	Equal	x == y	
!=	Not equal	x != y	
>	Greater than	x > y	
<	Less than	x < y	
>=	Greater than or equal to	x >= y	
<=	Less than or equal to	x <= y
##Python Arithmetic Operators
+	Addition	x + y	
-	Subtraction	x - y	
*	Multiplication	x * y	
/	Division	x / y	
%	Modulus	x % y	
**	Exponentiation	x ** y	
//	Floor division	x // y
##Python Bitwise Operators
& 	AND	Sets each bit to 1 if both bits are 1	x & y	
|	OR	Sets each bit to 1 if one of two bits is 1	x | y	
^	XOR	Sets each bit to 1 if only one of two bits is 1	x ^ y	
~	NOT	Inverts all the bits	~x	
<<	Zero fill left shift	Shift left by pushing zeros in from the right and let the leftmost bits fall off	x << 2	
>>	Signed right shift	Shift right by pushing copies of the leftmost bit in from the left, and let the rightmost bits fall off	x >> 2
##Operator Precedence
`print((6 + 3) - (6 + 3))`
Parentheses has the highest precedence, meaning that expressions inside parentheses must be evaluated first:
Multiplication * has higher precedence than addition +, and therefor multiplications are evaluated before additions:
`print(100 + 5 * 3)`
#The precedence order is described in the table below, starting with the highest precedence at the top:

()	Parentheses	
**	Exponentiation	
+x  -x  ~x	Unary plus, unary minus, and bitwise NOT	
*  /  //  %	Multiplication, division, floor division, and modulus	
+  -	Addition and subtraction	
<<  >>	Bitwise left and right shifts	
&	Bitwise AND	
^	Bitwise XOR	
|	Bitwise OR	
==  !=  >  >=  <  <=  is  is not  in  not in 	Comparisons, identity, and membership operators	
not	Logical NOT	
and	AND	
or	OR

quiz.question: What is the result of 5 + 2?
What operator is used for exponentiation in Python?

python.title: Python Lists, Tuples, Sets
python.content:
#Python Lists, Tuples, Sets
##Lists, tuples, and sets are data structures used to store collections of items in Python. Lists are mutable, ordered collections, while tuples are immutable. Sets are unordered collections with no duplicate elements.
python.lesson:
`# List
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
# Tuple
colors = ("red", "green", "blue")
# Set
numbers = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}`
##List
Lists are used to store multiple items in a single variable.

Lists are one of 4 built-in data types in Python used to store collections of data, the other 3 are Tuple, Set, and Dictionary, all with different qualities and usage.

Lists are created using square brackets:
`thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(thislist)`
##List Items
List items are ordered, changeable, and allow duplicate values.

List items are indexed, the first item has index [0], the second item has index [1] etc.
##Ordered
When we say that lists are ordered, it means that the items have a defined order, and that order will not change.

If you add new items to a list, the new items will be placed at the end of the list.
##Allow Duplicates
Since lists are indexed, lists can have items with the same value:
`thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "apple", "cherry"]
print(thislist)`
##List Length
`thislist = ["apple", "banana", "cherry"]
print(len(thislist))`

quiz.question: Which data type in Python is ordered and mutable?
What is the correct syntax for creating a tuple?

python.title: Python Dictionaries
python.content:
#Python Dictionaries
##Dictionaries are data structures used to store key-value pairs in Python. Each key is associated with a value, allowing for efficient lookup and retrieval of data.
##Use dictionaries to store and retrieve data in key-value pairs. Dictionaries are useful for representing structured data and organizing information in your programs.
python.lesson:
##Dictionaries are used to store data values in key:value pairs.

A dictionary is a collection which is ordered*, changeable and do not allow duplicates.
`thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
print(thisdict)`
##Dictionary Items
Dictionary items are ordered, changeable, and do not allow duplicates.

Dictionary items are presented in key:value pairs, and can be referred to by using the key name.
`thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964
}
print(thisdict["brand"])`
##Ordered or Unordered?
When we say that dictionaries are ordered, it means that the items have a defined order, and that order will not change.

Unordered means that the items do not have a defined order, you cannot refer to an item by using an index.
##Changeable
Dictionaries are changeable, meaning that we can change, add or remove items after the dictionary has been created.
##Duplicates Not Allowed
Dictionaries cannot have two items with the same key:

`thisdict = {
  "brand": "Ford",
  "model": "Mustang",
  "year": 1964,
  "year": 2020
}
print(thisdict)`

quiz.question: How are items stored in a dictionary?
What happens if you try to access a key that does not exist in a dictionary?

python.title: Python If…Else
python.content:
#Python If…Else
## If...else statements are used to make decisions in Python based on certain conditions. They allow your program to execute different code blocks depending on whether a condition is true or false.
##Use if...else statements to control the flow of your program and perform different actions based on specific conditions. They are essential for implementing logic and making your programs more dynamic.
python.lesson:
#Python Conditions and If statements
Python supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:
Equals: a == b
Not Equals: a != b
Less than: a < b
Less than or equal to: a <= b
Greater than: a > b
Greater than or equal to: a >= b
`Example:
x = 5
if x > 3:
    print("x is greater than 3")
else:
    print("x is less than or equal to 3")`
#Indentation
Python relies on indentation (whitespace at the beginning of a line) to define scope in the code. Other programming languages often use curly-brackets for this purpose.

##Elif
The elif keyword is Python's way of saying "if the previous conditions were not true, then try this condition".
`a = 33
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
elif a == b:
  print("a and b are equal")`

##Else
The else keyword catches anything which isn't caught by the preceding conditions.
`a = 200
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
elif a == b:
  print("a and b are equal")
else:
  print("a is greater than b")`

In this example a is greater than b, so the first condition is not true, also the elif condition is not true, so we go to the else condition and print to screen that "a is greater than b".

You can also have an else without the elif:

`a = 200
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
else:
  print("b is not greater than a")`


##Short Hand If
If you have only one statement to execute, you can put it on the same line as the if statement.
`if a > b: print("a is greater than b")`

##And
The and keyword is a logical operator, and is used to combine conditional statements:
`a = 200
b = 33
c = 500
if a > b and c > a:
  print("Both conditions are True")`
##Or
The or keyword is a logical operator, and is used to combine conditional statements:
`a = 200
b = 33
c = 500
if a > b or a > c:
  print("At least one of the conditions is True")`

##Not
The not keyword is a logical operator, and is used to reverse the result of the conditional statement:
`a = 33
b = 200
if not a > b:
  print("a is NOT greater than b")`

#Nested If
You can have if statements inside if statements, this is called nested if statements.
`x = 41

if x > 10:
  print("Above ten,")
  if x > 20:
    print("and also above 20!")
  else:
    print("but not above 20.")`

quiz.question: What keyword is used to start an if statement in Python?
What happens if no conditions in an if...elif...else statement are True?

python.title: Python While Loops
python.content:
#Python While Loops
## While loops are used to execute a block of code repeatedly as long as a specified condition is true. They continue iterating until the condition becomes false.
##Use while loops when you need to repeatedly execute a block of code until a certain condition is met. Be cautious to avoid infinite loops by ensuring that the condition eventually becomes false.
python.lesson:
`Example:
i = 0
while i < 5:
    print(i)
    i += 1`

##Python Loops
Python has two primitive loop commands:

while loops
for loops

##The break Statement
With the break statement we can stop the loop even if the while condition is true:
`i = 1
while i < 6:
  print(i)
  if i == 3:
    break
  i += 1`

##The continue Statement
`i = 0
while i < 6:
  i += 1
  if i == 3:
    continue
  print(i)`


##The else Statement
With the else statement we can run a block of code once when the condition no longer is true:
`i = 1
while i < 6:
  print(i)
  i += 1
else:
  print("i is no longer less than 6")`

quiz.question: What keyword is used to start a while loop in Python?
How do you exit a while loop prematurely?
